comments.commentBody: Awesome! If you are into Tamil film songs this is as good as they come.
Wishing a very happy Diwali to all humankind.
I LIKE THIS SONG.

Thanks for your comment. Reporters have often asked the Dalai Lama about the self-immolations, which have been happening for some two years now. He has spoken against these acts, and other forms of what he calls "extreme protest," like hunger strikes. More lately the task of public response has fallen to Lobsang Sangay, the kalon tripa, or prime minister.

An edict from the Dalai Lama would have an effect, of course, but there are divisions among Tibetans now about the appropriate responses/reactions/protests to Beijing's policies in Tibet and Tibetan areas. Many young Tibetans want a more aggressive approach, something more confrontational than the Dalai Lama's "Middle Way."

Forgot the chart of voter turnout in the U.S.:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voter_turnout_in_the_United_States_presiden...

The current state-by-state winner-take-all method of awarding electoral votes (not mentioned in the U.S. Constitution, but since enacted by 48 states), ensures that the candidates, after the conventions, in 2012 did not reach out to about 80% of the states and their voters. Candidates had no reason to poll, visit, advertise, organize, campaign, or care about the voter concerns in the dozens of states where they were safely ahead or hopelessly behind.

None of the 10 most rural states (VT, ME, WV, MS, SD, AR, MT, ND, AL, and KY) is a battleground state.
The current state-by-state winner-take-all method of awarding electoral votes does not enhance the influence of rural states, because the most rural states are not battleground states, and they are ignored.
Support for a national popular vote in rural states: VT–75%, ME–77%, WV–81%, MS–77%, SD–75%, AR–80%, MT–72%, KY–80%, NH–69%, IA–75%,SC–71%, NC–74%, TN–83%, WY–69%, OK–81%, AK–70%, ID–77%, WI–71%, MO–70%, and NE–74%.

Policies important to the citizens of non-battleground states are not as highly prioritized as policies important to ‘battleground’ states when it comes to governing.

**
With the current system, it could only take winning a bare plurality of popular votes in the 11 most populous states, containing 56% of the population of the U.S., for a candidate to win with a mere 26% of the nation's votes!

The overthrow of Mossedagh and establishment of the Shah Reza may be the key karmic choice from which all the ill in the region stems.
I suppose big oil forced Ike's hand, which let him later to complain about the military industrial complex.

Western countries have brought these conflicts on themselves. Going back to Ike, it was not just Lebanon and the Sinai invasion, it was his involvement in the overthrow of Mohammed Mossedagh the democratically elected president of Iran. That brought about the ascendency of the Shiites there. That was instigated at the behest of British Petroleum.

Before that it was the British dividing up the middle east giving despots control of artificial territories, along with defining the country boundaries between Pakistan and Afghanistan, putting tribes in separate countries instead of leaving them united.

The U.S. caved into Turkey and would not let the Kurds have their own country carved out of Iraq. They have proven to be the most stable of them all.

The Abbasids assassinated the Umayyads in Baghdad then moved their capital to Damascus. Now the descendents of these factions are fighting for dominance. The Jews and Christians who live among are threatened.. Finally enough Syrians became fed up with the Assad dictatorship, encouraged by the Arab Spring demanded more political freedom. The dictator Assad was not going to allow that.

Now we have several Arab countries vying to be the most influential there. Some people want the U.S. to intervene, to do what? We will not be able to unite these factions, and there is no charismatic leader for them to follow. All we can do is try to keep it from spreading beyond their borders.

"Federal legislation requires Election Day to be held on the first Tuesday after the first Monday every four years. Nothing in the Constitution grants federal institutions the power to postpone that date, according to the Congressional Research Service. However, it’s the states’ authority, not Washington’s, to administer federal elections, and a handful have passed into state law the power to postpone in emergency circumstances.”
http://tv.msnbc.com/2012/11/01/in-sandy-affected-communities-what-will-h...
Hideous.  Big color for big bucks.
It's unlikely to have any affect at all.
You are a perfect example of the individuals that populate America, specially in the left coast.
Never too late. Why not go now if you still believe it.

Violently? I don't see anyone hitting the streets protesting over this.

The problem and annoyance is that they're not just trying to treat according to interests and personalities: That's a very good thing.

The bad? They are also trying to wipe away any hints of gender identity, which is absurd. Despite what queer theory (their term, not mine) hopes for, humans naturally tend to see both a male and female category. And ironically enough, transgender individuals actually reinforce this rather than blur the line.

Do you want to solve the problem: Then convince society that feminine characteristics are not something to be ashamed of or somehow less worthy. You may not realize it, but your snide comment about a tiara and pink princess dress is a case-and-point of this terrible mindset.

Consider the famous case of the boy who was accidentally castrated during circumcision, and was given female genitals and raised as a girl. The "girl" hated girls' things. "She" wanted to play rough and tumble boys' games. As "she" grew up, despite being given female hormones, "she" developed a sexual attraction for women. Finally, they had to give in and give "her" sex change surgery so "she" could live as a man.

We should respect individual differences, but we are naive if we think that referring to little boys and girls with the same pronoun and treating them the same way is going to be beneficial. It will rather take most boys and most girls further from where instinct leads them, and it will make them less able at the roles they are likely to go into later in life -- do we really want to make too much of a scraped knee of a boy who is going to grow up to be a soldier?

As a boy who hated team sports and suffered for it I'm sympathetic to children who are pigeonholed, but the solution here isn't to force all the children into the same mold. Rather, it's to respect the affinities of children who, as I did, have different ones.
So.... just make gender neutral assumptions and offer universal encouragement. Don't deny the fundamentals of their native language.

I don't see why people are reacting so violently to this. No one is denying that these are boys and girls. They are just trying to treat them according to their interests and personalities, and not making gender-linked assumptions. I'd much rather see this than the current trend of sticking a tiara and pink princess dress on every girl upon birth.

Here is my question about the National Popular Vote Bill.  Let's say states with 271 electoral votes pass it, including Virginia and Washington.  Then there is an election where candidate A wins the popular vote, but candidate B sweeps the small states AND Virginia and Washington.  So the electoral college meets and all the big states vote for Candidate A because they promised under the NPVB, but when it gets to Virginia and Washington, they renege and vote for Candidate B.  What recourse would anyone have?   And instead of criticizing my hypothetical example (it might have some flaws in it), respond to the situation I am trying to capture:  one where the electors cheat, but their vote would still count, wouldn't it?

The "Play Against the Clock" link on the new puzzle home page STILL doesn't work; I had to get to it for Wednesday's puzzle through the "premium puzzle" link on the blog page.   What is wrong with your IT people?  This is truly unacceptable, especially in light of the bragging e-mail I received from the NYT today about the (ugly) new format.
Wow...relax.
It's unlikely to have any effect at all.
Social engineers, hastening arrival of a brave new world.  Do they dispense soma?

I do development work in Central Asia and witness the outcomes of a gender segregated society that favors males over females. While boys are given the opportunity to learn, experiment, express themselves and travel, girls are taught to be quiet, obedient, submissive and to serve others. They rarely leave the household and spend most of their time with other women. The outcome is tragic especially for women. Many of them remain dependent on men their entire lives and never experience freedom of choice and the sense of being equal. Although Central Asian men can appreciate a servile, docile wife, many of them are also not satisfied in such a relationship and say they would prefer a more equal partner. But to have one they would have to give up the perks of patriarchy, which is not easy for them. Since childhood they learned they are entitled because of their gender. Oh how I wish they went through a Swedish kindergarten!

Some will argue that the Swedes are overdoing this, that they are emasculating boys, etc. Please lets consider the unequal conditions most women on this planet live under. And then lets appreciate every single effort that's being made to create more quality between the sexes. Thank you, Sweden!

With haste pronouncements, France wants to play an outsize role in confilicts but treats US as its treasurer and Germany as the deputy. I thought Sarkozy was erratic, but it seems the whole psche of France as a nation is very insecure. Unfortunately, Syrians does not know what they are getting into, because civil war puts a lasting scar on a nation's culture which never ever recovers. And France just wants to feel good as a nation regardless of the fire it is igniting in faraway places with niave people.
Are they not badly scarred already?

I do not like that it is no longer possible to download the puzzle and solve it offline.  The power, and therefore, the internet is not always on but as long as my laptop was charged I could solve the puzzle.  I am disappointed also that I cannot take my Sunday puzzle with me on the airplane.

You are absolutely right, the only constructive solution is to stop funding the rebels to end the violence. Then democratic reform can be demanded as terms for rebuilding aid from EU. This is not a death match, it's a struggle for collective freedom. That freedom is best secured under peaceful conditions.

The key is Russia and China to a lesser extent.
But it is doubtful that Russia will play ball. They have an interest in seeing the West helpless in the face of this explosion. Russia has been Syria's backer militarly and economically. It lost prestige in the Yom Kipour War when Israel defeated the Russian backed regime, and was again defeated in the Afganistan War, lost as well to the West.
It is obvious that Russia has its eyes on the Middle East and the conflict plays into its hand.
Backing Iran and Syria is just as strategically serious as the West's interst in the Middle East.
And it certainly looks as if the West vs the East conflict is playing out in Syria.
David Gutholc

I don't know if what you suggest is the solution but at least you have an adult sized appreciation of the complexities. Every time I heard a Republican chicken hawk going on about us having to do more to support the rebels militarily I felt like grabbing them and asking them, "You do know which side of this fight the Christians are on, don't you?"

Not that that should be absolutely determinative of our policy, but I don't think their voter base would appreciate the irony.

"a United Nations-led multinational force to oversee it" is the key element of your suggestion, and it is not going to happen, NEVER. No nation, and no collection of nations, is going to put themselves into what the US did in Iraq.

There are no volunteers, and all candidates have been very open about seeing the dangers. Everyone wants someone else to do it. It often appears in the NYT that Israel wants Turkey to do it, both to have someone do it, and to do it to Turkey, two birds with one stone, but the Turks won't. Nobody else will either.

If we go along with the Saudi/Gulf Arab Sunni game of blowing up Syria in a civil war, an outside fueled war, then we are going to get what you have described so well. You are right, it can't be controlled without something that is NOT going to happen.

We need to stop this now. Shut down the rebels funded and supplied out of Turkey and Lebanon and Jordan.

Then we can work with Russia on a transition. If we blow it up first, there won't be anything to transition.
Social experiments that go awry?  Ah, yes, you must be thinking of Reaganomics, or deregulating the banks.  By comparison to that, it seems to me the Swedes are doing all right.
